instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.SMC_BC_OK: What is SMC_BC_OK? This is a typo of SMC_BC_ACOK When you see SMC_BC_OK, assume they meant to type SMC_BC_ACOK.
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2015 green light/no power/no fan
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2015 board liquid damaged with green light/no power/no fan. Damage was centralized on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.  Via to <CAPACITOR>C7500</CAPACITOR> to pin 23 on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> burned.

Replaced <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>. Voltage at pin 14 on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> .75v before chip changed. No change in voltage after chip changed, still .75v
Replaced <CAPACITOR>C7500</CAPACITOR> & <CAPACITOR>C7503</CAPACITOR>

Restored via with jumper on pin 23. Now have restored 8.65v after jumper installed.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>=.75v measured at <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR>
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>=0v
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>=2.96v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>=3.42v measured at <RESISTOR>R1451</RESISTOR>
PP5V__S4RS3=0
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>=2.88V measured at <RESISTOR>R1450</RESISTOR>

Any thoughts on what I need to track down to get this thing to turn on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2015 green light/no power/no fan
threads.message: Test with a battery plugged in. i know its silly but the past few 00165s have not been starting up without a battery for me.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2015 green light/no power/no fan
threads.message: OK. Thanks. Could very well be! I'll check it out!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2015 green light/no power/no fan
threads.message:
More measurements:

SMC PM G2 EN=3.42 at <RESISTOR>R5198</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_OK</SIGNAL>=3.09v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2015 green light/no power/no fan
threads.message: Ok so for one yes always test with battery once you get the S5 rails but this seems like more to it. 2.88 volts on <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is no good need to replace clock chip and inspect that area. After that, need to figure out why only 0.75 volts on <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2015 green light/no power/no fan
threads.message:
Do you think that if I inject 5v on the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> line at maybe <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR> I'd have a better chance of finding the short? I also tried with the battery but there is no change.

Looking for the short:
Removed 4820-.75v
Removed <CAPACITOR>C4810</CAPACITOR>-.82v
Removed <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR>-.81
Removed <CAPACITOR>C7400</CAPACITOR>-.81

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2015 green light/no power/no fan
threads.message: Yes but you need to address your PPVRTC problem first. That may even fix the problem

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2015 green light/no power/no fan
threads.message: What short?? What is resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2015 green light/no power/no fan
threads.message: I’ll check out the clock tomorrow and report findings. I will also measure in diode mode on 5V line.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2015 green light/no power/no fan
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> diode mode measured at <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR>=.479Ohms
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> diode mode measured at <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR>=.472Ohms
Looking for a replacement clock chip in my donor boards to replace this one with

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2015 green light/no power/no fan
threads.message: Changed clock chip out and now I have 3.41v on <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> pin 1. Now have .04v on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>.  I've already changed out the chip. Do you think that something else cooked it while I was messing around with <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>? Ugh

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2015 green light/no power/no fan
threads.message: No that means you have fixed the clock issue if it's a stable voltage, but now measure resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> could be bad soldering on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> but that sounds like a short

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2015 green light/no power/no fan
threads.message: Got the clock issue fixed but then suddenly now I have a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.  It was measuring 2v at F7140. I was looking around for something that was getting hot but couldn't identify anything. I injected voltage to the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> line and slowly added voltage up to 1v.  The CPU was heating up but I couldn't find any components that were hot via the old alcohol trick.  I plugged in the AC adapter and the green light came on and then I heard "pop".  The top of the CPU popped off right under the microscope.  What transistor allows voltage to pass directly to the CPU? This repair has been a PITA.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2015 green light/no power/no fan
threads.message: High side fet was shorted or you bridged something but RIP to that board
